Review Title: Nice line in a CV, don’t stay more than 2 years
Pros: The culture and benefits are great, and the company is very inclusive to everybody. You can choose if you want to work from home or the office, and the offices are always top notch. Very smart people are working in Criteo and it’s nice to be part of it.
Cons:
As the C-levels are super professional and smart, the intermediate and lower levels of leadership are SO bad. If you need anything which is a bit out of the box for your clients, no one will give you a hand or answers. In my team we had a 30 minute weekly team meeting plus 30 minutes of one-to-one with the team leader and that’s it, if you need anything else the managers will give you the feeling that you are nudging them and wasting their time.
Growing within the company is almost impossible, both horizontally and vertically. There is an inner company system for career development but the fact is that it’s impossible to grow because so many positions were switched to temporary internships contracts, kicking out the permanent staff in order to bring a cheap workforce to be changed every 6-9 months.

Cons: Pay is lower in comparison to other players in the industry. Frequent comp changes that do not benefit ICs. The constantly evolving industry is generally a challenege.

Pros: The job is okay as a stepping stone and certainly provides you with experiences, but I don’t see a quality future here for anyone. I would rate this company lower if I could.
Cons: The sales team quite honestly feels like a Highschool. The managers are not trained for their positions, they are in the positions because they joined Criteo at a time when Criteo prospered and “proved” themselves when all it took was spamming clients into oblivion. They do not know how to offer advice, they will only look out for themselves, and have on many occasions said things that should have been cause for HR reprimands. But hey, that’s just sales. This job causes undue stress and they will encourage you to work overtime and will reward the most nonsensical luck as if it were proven strategy. There are better jobs out there but if you’re in a pinch the benefits are great and the pay is decent. The name isn’t too bad on a resume either

Review Title: One of the best place to work at
Pros: Criteo is an excellent company to work for! I spent 5years there, learning new things everyday. The company culture is the same you may find in a small startup : everyone helping each other, everything is made to make you feel you’re unique. I learnt a lot! Your colleague are passionate by their job and you’ll share lot of great conversations. You have a lot of liberty, many teams you could join if you want to switch from one subject to another. I’m really grateful I had the opportunity to work there and suggest anyone to take it.
Cons: Lot of challenges, if you don’t know how to organize Your schedule, you may found yourself working “too much” (too much not meaning you’re productive)

Pros: Such a wonderful company, flexible work policy, amazing culture!

Pros: Great product! Hopeful for the future!
Cons:
I’ve been with Criteo for less than one year. I was very pleased to receive an offer. 

Today, I was laid off from Criteo. In a five minute digital meeting with my boss, she informed me that my position was eliminated (“a reduction in force, decision not reflective of my performance, return your laptop in 30 days, etc.”), and then she left the meeting so that the HR Manager could provide the logistics of my unplanned departure. The end.

This is not my first time being laid off. It is, however, the first time that a lay off felt impersonal. As I was signing my digital paperwork, my boss shot over to me a message via Slack, saying, “So sorry. Best of luck!” No messages from the leaders or the team. Four individual colleagues reached out to share their sadness, appreciation and best wishes before my systems access was shut off. That’s all. I truly feel like a number who was erased. What happened to the relationships that I had established? Did I mean nothing to them? Any appreciation? Did I achieve anything? It feels like a year of my life wasted. 

If this is the Future of Work, I don’t want it.

Review Title: Wake up call - We're heading to the wrong direction
Pros: The job itself can be exciting, interesting approach for management style. Remote option is great! There were many nice, ambitious and talented people - before layoffs happened.
Cons: Only been here for 2 years but this company has been doing a MAJOR shift. Used to be a caring, friendly company with lots of talent and very nice initiatives for employee wellbeing. But right now the gap between what is being said - everything is amazing - and the reality of employees is massive! C-level management seems to be completely disconnected from it's employees - this urgently needs to be fixed or it's is not gonna end well. Very sad to see this happening.

Pros: One the best company to work in France. great people and great product
Cons: many changes the last few months

Review Title: The right place to growth within a turbulent business
Pros: Criteo is the right place to learn. Super smart benevolent people with high expectations. I felt valued and encouraged to grow. Good compensation. Loved my time there.
Cons: Business is undergoing up and downs. It's best to know. It's fully flexible which might be lonely at times if you come to the office often.

Cons: Hypergrowth is not there anymore so limited career opportunities for new hires.

Review Title: Interviewed with recruiter. Couldn't have been more rude and unprofessional.
Pros: less than stellar interview with a recruiter at Crito
Cons: Went through a first call with recruiter at Criteo...When discussing salary + commission there was a disconnect, the position was probably alittle more entry-levelish or maybe just very low paying. When I learned what the OTE was, I explained that # is what I was looking for my base alone.... Which is fine! There was a disconnect and it's better to get these things out early in the interview process rather than later. The recruiters response was " well good luck with that. I don't see that anywhere out there at all". Continued to be smug about what I said. Apparently this person knows all of the media advertising space! What an absolute pleasure to speak on the phone with someone so knowledgeable and professional. Next time, just say "At that price point, I'd suggest to keep your eye open for a more senior role here". What an embarrassment. I could cringe writing this, but he spoke like I haven't been making that $$ as a base for the last 3 years....It was a disconnect for sure, but know how to speak to people.

Pros: Working at Criteo, a global technology company specializing in digital advertising, can offer several advantages and opportunities. Here are some pros of working at Criteo: Cutting-edge technology: Criteo is at the forefront of digital advertising and utilizes advanced technology and algorithms to deliver personalized and effective ad campaigns. Working at Criteo gives you the opportunity to work with state-of-the-art tools and technologies. Impactful work: Criteo's advertising solutions reach millions of users globally, enabling businesses to connect with their target audience. As an employee, you can contribute to creating impactful campaigns and help shape the digital advertising landscape. Dynamic and collaborative environment: Criteo fosters a dynamic and collaborative work environment. You'll have the chance to collaborate with talented professionals from diverse backgrounds, including data scientists, engineers, marketers, and business experts. This collaborative culture encourages innovation and learning.
Cons: Fast-paced and demanding environment: Criteo operates in a highly competitive industry, and the work environment can be fast-paced and demanding. Deadlines and client expectations may require working under pressure and managing multiple tasks simultaneously.

Pros: Nice people and a decent salary for Barcelona

Review Title: Equality first, good place to work

Review Title: Not racially diverse in middle and upper management.
Pros: Having worked at a multitude of tech companies, I have a hard time thinking where Criteo stands out. Yes, the benefits are decent - as they are at any tech company. The company is trying to reinvent itself but its highest margin product (retargeting) has a limited shelf life and continues to decline, which then impacts the overall environment.
Cons: What is absolutely grating is the gap between talk and action on diversity. Yes, there is talk of diversity and programs and so on. But where it counts - leadership and upper management, there is no diversity. From C level down to VP level, at least as far as the US is concerned, you will be hard pressed to see a black or brown face. Yes, there are plenty of women - all caucasian. So its like the Mad Men era, except they decided to let only those who were in the office ( men and women) now join management.

Review Title: Best work culture and learning opportunities
Pros: - Flexible work. - Management supports you in every form. - Employee first policy. - You get everything you want to learn and grow personally. - The onboarding process is well-defined and robust. - The work-life balance is great. - You will always grow technically both in your professional and personal life.
Cons: - Only one thing. You have to train on your own if your manager is not good. - Another thing, if your manager thinks you are not useful (even though you are), you will be forced to resign.

Pros: -much like any other company, your boss will make or break you. I was lucky I had a manager who are passionate about the product, a hunter, overall set a great example for me. - there's already a system in place for most things. This can be quite overwhelming at the beginning, but will be helpful after a certain time. - can be fully remote if you prefer - great benefit (salary, commission, full coverage insurance)
Cons: - people are not very willing to help. No one is going to hold your hand so be ready to learn everything by yourself. - some people are just very lazy, barely do any work, and some leaders are just lousy and expect you to understand everything from day 1 without willing to lift a finger to help. for some reason these people have survived the lay-off while new employees who are hard working and eager to learn being let go. - recent layoff

Review Title: Good Company - Unfortunate Ending for many
Pros: -Culture -Benefits (Health Insurance is like $6/month out of your paycheck - they cover more than most companies) -Compensation is strong - salary isn't great but it's made up with quarterly bonus that's a 70/30 split. Competitors do have stronger salaries but less bonus... -
Cons: -You have to work Thanksgiving Weekend (But we did get a bonus the past 2 years for it). -Significant layoffs a few weeks ago which seemed due to some unfortunate factors from some mismanagement at the top. Criteo lost a 65M lawsuit in Europe due to a data breach and rumors of a sale - It's still corporate America so this stuff happens even at companies that pride themselves on their values and workplace culture. -Ad ops and Analytics seem to not be properly staffed (overworked).

Cons: - As with all tech, there will always be difficulties and maintenance required, but consistent issues prevent efficient workflows and increased client frustration - New features/improvements always rolling out without fixing previous problems, getting ahead of themselves - Holiday (Q4) quotas are near impossible to hit
